Smile back at the world: Renowned photographer Edward Steichen shot this image of a smiling tourist on the steps of the Royal Hawaiian Hotel for a 1937 Matson campaign. Attractive women, both tourists and locals, featured prominently in ads of the day. Now called just the Royal Hawaiian , the luxury hotel on Waikiki Beach has a free exhibition of Matson travel posters and other memorabilia on display through April 2016. Photo: Matson Smile back at the world: Renowned photographer Edward Steichen... Image 2 of 9 
Hawaii welcomes you: Celebrity photographer Anton Bruehl "created a vibrant illusion of tropical outdoor life in a series of advertisements featuring beautiful women as tourists and exotic Hawaiian models," according to Matson archivist Lynn Blocker Krantz. Selected by a San Francisco ad agency for a 1937-38 Matson campaign, Bruehl shot it entirely in his New York studio on Lexington Avenue. This 1938 ad focuses on the Hawaiian value of hospitality and traditional lei greeting, rather than a pretty tourist. Photo: Matson Hawaii welcomes you: Celebrity photographer Anton Bruehl "created... Image 3 of 9 
The silver surf of Waikiki: Edward Steichen shot this image for the Royal Hawaiian Hotel’s 1935 promotional booklet. Matson Navigation Company opened the Waikiki hotel in 1927 to encourage travel on its ships to Hawaii from San Francisco. Interested travelers could contact Matson’s travel offices and other agencies in Honolulu, New York, Chicago, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Seattle, Portland, Sydney and London. Photo: Matson The silver surf of Waikiki: Edward Steichen shot this image for the... Image 4 of 9 
Poster girl Pualani Mossman: The image of a beautiful Hawaiian woman has been associated with Hawaii travel for many years. Born in Honolulu in 1916, Pualani Mossman danced hula at the opening of Matson’s Royal Hawaiian Hotel in 1927, was picked by the Hawaii Tourist Bureau to appear in the first color movie filmed in Hawaii, 1934’s "Song of the Islands," and in 1937 was photographed by Anton Bruehl for a nation Matson ad campaign with a red hibiscus in her hair. She became known as the "Matson girl" from then on, and continued to dance hula in Hawaii and her later home in Florida until her death at age 89. The image of a woman with a flower in her hair on Hawaiian Airlines’ planes is also called Pualani. Photo: Matson Poster girl Pualani Mossman: The image of a beautiful Hawaiian... Image 5 of 9 
Hawaii the voyage the world hopes to make: Edward Steichen shot black-and-white and color photographs for Matson ads, including this one, aboard the Lurline on his first trip to Hawaii in 1934. The Matson ads of the era, some of the first to use Kodachrome color film, initially focused on the voyage more than the destination. Photo: Matson Hawaii the voyage the world hopes to make: Edward Steichen shot... Image 6 of 9 
Nothing compares with life in Hawaii: Edward Steichen took the photo for this Matson ad in Hawaii in 1936. "The huge success of the ads unleashed a wave of tourism to Hawaii and the South Pacific," according to Matson archivist Lynn Blocker Krantz. Photo: Matson Nothing compares with life in Hawaii: Edward Steichen took the... Image 7 of 9 
Royal Hawaiian booklet: Matson hired Edward Steichen shoot photographs for the Royal Hawaiian promotional booklet in 1934-35, and hired him again in 1940-41 for a national ad campaign that focused more on the unique qualities of being in Hawaii. Photo: Matson Royal Hawaiian booklet: Matson hired Edward Steichen shoot... Image 8 of 9 
"Let’s Go to Alohaland: Romantic Hawaii," a recently discovered and digitized 29-minute promotional film made by Matson Navigation Company, is the centerpiece of a new exhibit at Filoli in Woodside. When you think of traveling to Hawaii, what do you see? An exotic tropical destination, a glamorous resort, a playground for ocean adventure or the cradle of a vibrant ancient culture, now part of an intoxicating mix with later arrivals? Perhaps it’s a combination of these images, and more, with a helping of whatever the latest media campaign (e.g. #LetHawaiiHappen) wants you to envision. 
While many in California now have strong family ties or memories of frequent vacations in the Hawaiian Islands, the Aloha State was more of a blank slate to most when the Matson Navigation Company began promoting passenger travel to Hawaii more than a century ago. Related Stories
